title: Chinese Embassy in South Africa Donates Books and Audio Materials in Chinese to Library in South African
description: On July 19, 2016,  for International Mandela Day, the Chinese Embassy of South Africa presented books and audio-visual materials introducing Chinese history and culture to the Brooklyn Library in South Africa.  The Chinese Embassy Culture Counselor attended the book-giving ceremony on behalf of the embassy.   During the handover ceremony, Counselor Zheng also presented stationary to the orphanage children in attendance, and introduced them to Chinese culture. The event was an important part of the new program launched by the Embassy in South Africa, "Chinese Books Entering the South African Library" (may have slightly different name due to translation). Since the beginning of this year, the embassy has also donated books to the Mossel Bay City Library, the Kara heritage Institute, and the Bitolo Kangchangte Library.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy in South Africa Donates Books and Audio Materials in Chinese to Library in South African

# Description
On July 19, 2016,  for International Mandela Day, the Chinese Embassy of South Africa presented books and audio-visual materials introducing Chinese history and culture to the Brooklyn Library in South Africa.  The Chinese Embassy Culture Counselor attended the book-giving ceremony on behalf of the embassy.   During the handover ceremony, Counselor Zheng also presented stationary to the orphanage children in attendance, and introduced them to Chinese culture. The event was an important part of the new program launched by the Embassy in South Africa, "Chinese Books Entering the South African Library" (may have slightly different name due to translation). Since the beginning of this year, the embassy has also donated books to the Mossel Bay City Library, the Kara heritage Institute, and the Bitolo Kangchangte Library.
justification: Project focuses on cultural exchange and education through book donations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of books and audio materials, cultural exchange focus, education sector

title: China donates teaching planetariums and Chinese textbooks to Sci-Bono Discovery Centre
description: On March 7, 2016, a ceremony was held for the donation of a teaching planetarium and 2,000 Chinese textbooks to the Sci-Bono Discovery Centre, a science museum in Johannesburg. The planetarium was donated by China Education Equipment and Instrument Co., Ltd., and the Chinese textbooks were donated by Confucius Institute Headquarters. The total amount of funding allocated for these donations is unknown.
staff_comments: as Chinese textbooks are involved, the project is coded as some development (partly representational).
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China donates teaching planetariums and Chinese textbooks to Sci-Bono Discovery Centre

# Description
On March 7, 2016, a ceremony was held for the donation of a teaching planetarium and 2,000 Chinese textbooks to the Sci-Bono Discovery Centre, a science museum in Johannesburg. The planetarium was donated by China Education Equipment and Instrument Co., Ltd., and the Chinese textbooks were donated by Confucius Institute Headquarters. The total amount of funding allocated for these donations is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on educational equipment and materials donation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of teaching planetarium and Chinese textbooks to science museum

title: ZTE loans USD 7.407 million to Cell C for unspecified purposes
description: In 2016, Chinese telecommunications company ZTE loaned USD 7.407 million through bridge vendor financing to Cell C, a South African telecommunications company, for unspecified purposes.   The financing had an interest rate of six-month Libor + 3.5%(1.058% + 3.5%=4.558%) and a contractual interest rate of 6.4%, accrued monthly and settled biannually. As of May 31, 2019, the outstanding loan amount was USD 151,000. The loan is set to expire on October 13, 2021.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
ZTE loans USD 7.407 million to Cell C for unspecified purposes

# Description
In 2016, Chinese telecommunications company ZTE loaned USD 7.407 million through bridge vendor financing to Cell C, a South African telecommunications company, for unspecified purposes.   The financing had an interest rate of six-month Libor + 3.5%(1.058% + 3.5%=4.558%) and a contractual interest rate of 6.4%, accrued monthly and settled biannually. As of May 31, 2019, the outstanding loan amount was USD 151,000. The loan is set to expire on October 13, 2021.
justification: Loan for unspecified purposes in telecommunications sector with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Unspecified purposes, telecommunications sector, financial transaction nature

title: Establishment of China-South Africa Computational Astrophysics Research Center
description: On November 21, 2016, the National Astronomical Observatory of China and the Astrophysics and Cosmology Research Unit at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (中国南非双边计算天体物理学联合中心) held the opening ceremony for the joint China-South Africa Computational Astrophysics Research Center in Durban. Professor Albert van Jaarsveld, President of KwaZulu-Nite University, and Prof. Xuelei Chen, a representative entrusted by Director of National Astronomical Observatory Yan Jun, signed the agreement on the establishment of the joint center, which was signed by Thomas Auf der Heyde, Deputy Minister of Science and Technology of South Africa Kong Minghui, Director of the Science Department witnessed the signature  In March of 2015, the two sides visited each other and signed a cooperation agreement. On November 3, 2016, Hou Lihong, Science and Technology Counselor of the Embassy in South Africa, and his entourage visited KwaZulu-Natal University to promote pragmatic cooperation in the field of Central and South Astronomy. Counselor Hou Lihong and his party attended the bilateral astronomical cooperation seminar between the National Astronomical Observatory of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and KwaZulu-Natal University.   It is unclear how much funding was allocated for this project and which Chinese government entity provided funding.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Establishment of China-South Africa Computational Astrophysics Research Center

# Description
On November 21, 2016, the National Astronomical Observatory of China and the Astrophysics and Cosmology Research Unit at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (中国南非双边计算天体物理学联合中心) held the opening ceremony for the joint China-South Africa Computational Astrophysics Research Center in Durban. Professor Albert van Jaarsveld, President of KwaZulu-Nite University, and Prof. Xuelei Chen, a representative entrusted by Director of National Astronomical Observatory Yan Jun, signed the agreement on the establishment of the joint center, which was signed by Thomas Auf der Heyde, Deputy Minister of Science and Technology of South Africa Kong Minghui, Director of the Science Department witnessed the signature  In March of 2015, the two sides visited each other and signed a cooperation agreement. On November 3, 2016, Hou Lihong, Science and Technology Counselor of the Embassy in South Africa, and his entourage visited KwaZulu-Natal University to promote pragmatic cooperation in the field of Central and South Astronomy. Counselor Hou Lihong and his party attended the bilateral astronomical cooperation seminar between the National Astronomical Observatory of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and KwaZulu-Natal University.   It is unclear how much funding was allocated for this project and which Chinese government entity provided funding.
justification: Project focuses on academic research collaboration in astrophysics without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of joint research center for computational astrophysics, academic cooperation agreement

title: Transnet signs contract for $337 million cross-currency interest rate swap with China Development Bank
description: According to the annual Financial Statement of Transnet in 2016, as of March 31, 2016, South African state-owned transportation company Transnet was party to a cross-currency interest rate swap for USD 337 million with the China Development Bank (CDB). In this transaction, both parties simultaneously loaned to each other but at different interest rates. The hedge interest rate payable by Transnet was 3-month JIBAR + 4.35%, and the hedge interest rate receivable by Transnet was 3-month LIBOR + 2.57%. According to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, the average 3-month JIBAR over 2016 was 4.93%, so at the time of signing the hedge interest rate payable was 9.28%. In this time period, the average 6-month LIBOR over 2016 was 1.056%, so at the time of signing the hedge interest rate receivable was 3.626%. Payments on the loan would be made quarterly until June 2030.
staff_comments: 1. The time when the swap took place is unknown, so AidData uses 3-month average monthly rates over 2016.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Transnet signs contract for $337 million cross-currency interest rate swap with China Development Bank

# Description
According to the annual Financial Statement of Transnet in 2016, as of March 31, 2016, South African state-owned transportation company Transnet was party to a cross-currency interest rate swap for USD 337 million with the China Development Bank (CDB). In this transaction, both parties simultaneously loaned to each other but at different interest rates. The hedge interest rate payable by Transnet was 3-month JIBAR + 4.35%, and the hedge interest rate receivable by Transnet was 3-month LIBOR + 2.57%. According to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, the average 3-month JIBAR over 2016 was 4.93%, so at the time of signing the hedge interest rate payable was 9.28%. In this time period, the average 6-month LIBOR over 2016 was 1.056%, so at the time of signing the hedge interest rate receivable was 3.626%. Payments on the loan would be made quarterly until June 2030.
justification: The project is a financial transaction involving interest rate swaps and does not have direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Cross-currency interest rate swap, financial transaction between Transnet and China Development Bank
